column11: Review Text

This stupa was a mound until rebuilt in the 1980's... so not remotely original.  Having said  that, this is a popular site with many buddhist pilgrims.  It is large and elegant with all the usual temple elements

column8: A lovely large stupa but perhaps not as featured as it is smaller than others nearby
column11: A lovely large stupa but perhaps not as featured as it is smaller than another white stupa, Ruwanwelisaya, and considerably smaller than the red brick Jethawanaramaya but nevertheless a significant attractive structure.
This is very old beautiful Buddhist temple. Now it looks like as if rebuilt. Lots of local Buddhist pilgrims in white.
This is also built by King Dutugemunu after beating battle with Tamil King Elara. One if Buddha's relics kept inside this.

column8: Stop by here for 15 - 30 minutes on your way back to town
column11: Although located close to the “Sacred City” Archaeological Park north of Anuradhapura, Mirissawatiya Dagoba is not actually inside the paid area. In other words, it’s free entry to this one. I guess it’s largely because it remains a practising place of worship. This means (a) much has been restored and (b) you have to take off your shoes and headwear. Good for a 20-minute walk-around. Despite recent restorations, there are stone fragments from long ago. These are worth a closer look. There's also a colourful myth attached to the founding of this place; read it up. General info about places in the “Sacred City/Ancient Ruins” park: The sights are quite spread out such that while walking from one sight to the second may be possible, covering many more on foot is impractical. You’ll need a bicycle or a tuktuk hired for the day. Also, there’s little shade from the sun, few places to buy water and even fewer toilets. Be prepared.

column8: 192 meter Glorious  Mirisaveti Stupa Having a Lovely landscape with Rock Caves .
column11: This site is a little off the standard route through the historic site but worth a visit.  It is somewhat hidden in the forest there but ask your guide for directions. This is stupa is the first stupa built by King Dutugemunu (161-137 BC). The present height is 192 m. This has been restored recently, it was in ruins, but restored to its original state. It has many legends & something to do with a Chilli curry, hence the name "Mirisavetiya" Miris means chilli in Sinhala.  This temple is full of history. Be dressed appropriately as a mark of respect for Buddhism. It has a lovely landscape with rock caves and superb views from the platform. It's not as huge and as ancient-looking as the Jethawanaramaya but it's still glorious to behold and worth a visit and take pictures. This is a  large and very nice looking white stupa. It helps to wear socks as walking up to the site on the very hot stones and sand pathways can be very difficult in bare feet This is ignored by most pilgrims but you will find peace and serenity on your walk around the place which is composed of the stupa, the Bo Tree and the Buddha image. All of this embedded in This is a small Stupa Compared to others you can see in Anuradhapura. But the Stone Pillars left off the outer dome which may have covered the "Stupa" originally is indeed something that you cannot see at other places too. It is a holy place. Buy flowers to place them in offering stand. It is well worth visiting this place, but make sure it is not in the afternoon as the sun makes the place hot.  You are not allowed to cover our heads & feet (except wearing of socks as a mark of respect) . it is better to visit this place, early morning, mid-morning or late evening Do not miss! The walk is easy on your feet as the grounds are mainly grass.

column8: One of the must visit place in Anuradapura
column11: This Mirisaweti Sthupa is one of the 8 sacred places in Anuradapura. If you travel by train very short distance from railway station. You can get taxi infront of Anuradapura railway station. They have some packages too. Short dresses are not allowed to this place. If you go at day time it is very difficult to go around sthupa. Because of heavy sunlight floor is so hot. Evening or early morning is the best time. I went on evening 5.30 p.m . Very calm place at that time. On poya days and sundays big rush there. This is one of the pagoda which made by king Dutugamunu. He also made Ruwanweliseya which is largest pagoda. Clean place. Parking space available. If you are buddhist, this is one of the must visit place in Sri Lanka.

Mirisawetiya is one of very first stupas in Sri Lanka which is built by the great King Dutugemunu. The stupa was a part of the Mirisawetiya Monastery. The remains of the buildings of the monastery still can be seen around the stupa. The 'Vahalkada' (frontispiece) is fine example of the height of artistic ability of the people of that era. The sight of the stupa is really beautiful. It is better if you can avoid noon to visit the place. It will be kind of hard for your feet, you know why.

Like a smaller, quieter version of Ruwanwelisaya.  Not part of the main ticket scheme but the donations seemed optional, so I gave 100.  Take a look at the two indents, where you can the see the details of the brick construction.
It is a big stupa, impressive to see and hear the story about the stupa. We went there in the weekend and it is nice to see what this place means for the people of Sri Lanka.
Easily accessible. Visible from a distance, looks a lot like Ruwanweliseya from the distance, but is much smaller.
Built 21 centuries ago. Close to the Anuradhapura heritage sites. This historical site has been renovated. Evening visits could be more convenient because of the warm weather.

Visited the place last Wednesday around 6.30 pm. Calm and quiet place to worship..  one of the Stupas built by great King Dutugemunu.. refurbished three decades ago ... it's believed that king has deposited his victory pole and build this Stupa... this is one of the eight sacred places situated in Anuradhapura sacred city.. Better to visit this place during week days and avoid weekends... Poya days,specially during Poson season ( June month ) Mirisavetiya will be heavily crowded. Best time to visit will be week days after 4 pm to have the better of it.
Beautiful white covered stupa much rebuilt with a famous front piece , again recently restored called a Vahalkada which is worth the visit

One of the pagoda which build by great king Dutu-Gamunu. Comparing to other stupas this is big stupa but surrounding area is seems little bit smaller. Since this place situated near by Anuradhapura city visit the place and get the experience.
Lots of monkeys in the parking area. Walked around the stupa and found some other ruins on the grounds. The stupa is huge but not much to see.
It's the start of the visit to the sacred town of Anuradhapura, according to Buddhist belief. I had a good guide, and we went from one temple (Stupa) to another in around half-day

Place of interest for Buddhist follower. Appropriate long clothes that covers body recommended. It is huge Stupa. There is a small temple with Idol of Lord Buddha besides it. Must visit place for history lovers.

Mirisavetiya Stupa was built in 2nd century BC by great Sri Lankan King Dutugamunu (disobedient Gamunu), an interesting character of Sri Lankan history who ruled from 161-137 BC. He is known as great warrior and builder king. His name is associated with the construction of 3 of the Atamasthana (eight sacred places of Anuradhapura) namely Ruwanwelisaya Dagoba and Lovamahapaya Monastery besides Mirisaveti Stupa.

A temple of historical value built by King Dutugamunu,  who was one of Sri-Lankas greatest kings. This temple is full of history. Be dressed appropriately as a mark of respect for Buddhism. Best time to visit is early morning to about 11 am & after 4pm in the evening as it can get very hot.
A large and very nice looking white stupa. It helps to wear socks as walking up to the  site on the very hot stones and sand pathways can be very difficult in bare feet

This site is a little off the standard route through the historic site but worth a visit. Renovations are still to be completed and the site has probably the most original atmosphere to it. It is somewhat hidden in the forest there but ask your guide for directions. Ignored by most pilgrims, you will find peace and serenity on your walk around the place which is composed of the stupa, the Bo Tree and the Buddha image. All of this embedded in a lovely landscape with rock caves and superb views from the platform. Do not miss! The walk is easy on your feet as the grounds are mainly grass.
There are many stories around this. What I know is that this was built by king dutugemunu for having a curry made out of chili without offering to Mahasanga.
It's not as huge and as ancient-looking as the Jethawanaramaya but it's still glorious to behold -- worth a visit and a pic

Mirisaveti Stupa is not as large as Jetavanaramaya or Ruwanelissiya.Neverthless this is another impressive stupa. Again another functioning temple and hence need to remove the footwear. Do wear socks to protect yourself from the hot stone flooring, if you are visiting during noon time.

This Stupa was built by King Dutugemunu. The Name Mirisawetiya Roughly Translates to Chilli Curry. According to "Mahawansa" The King went to Thisawewa for a bath and he left his scepter containing holy relics of Lor d Buddha on this spot on high ground. When he tried to lift it on his way to the palace after his bath he found he could not lift it. Also He remembered that during the war he once ate a Chilli Curry without offering Alms to Sanga. So He built this Stupa Around the Sceptre and named it " Mirisawetiya" This is a small Stupa Compared to others you can see in Anuradhapura. But the Stone Pillars left off the outer dome which may have covered the "Stupa" originally is indeed something that you cannot see at other places

it was dilapidated. What you see is the new one (by the cultural Triangle Fund). Time is nothing in this place. New or old, it is a holy place. Buy flowers to put them in sactuaries. Touch the foot in metal on the left.
This is stupa is the first stupa built by King Dutugemunu (161-137 BC). The present height is 192 m.

This wonderful monument built by King Dutugamunu has been restored recently, it was in ruins, but restored to its original state. It has many legends & something to do with a Chilli curry, hence the name "Mirisavetiya" Miris means chilli in Sinhala. Well worth visiting this place, but make sure its not in the afternoon as the sun makes the place hot, since we are not allowed to cover our heads &  feet(as a mark of respect) its better to visit this place, early morning, mid morning or late evening.

Visited this site as part of a 17-day Bunnik Tours. Solid structure that has a 1 1/2m crystal at the very top. Takes over 2 months to repaint this structure. The circle on the paver's represents the dome @ the very top of the Stupa. Quite an outstanding engineering feat and well worth a visit.

The huge white stupa impresses every single tourist. Mirisavatiya Dagoba has been built by King Dutugamunu, the one who defeated the Tamil invaders who ruled the country for 30 years and brought the country under one ruler. After his consecration he left his sceptre which had a scared relic of Buddha inside, on this location. When he returned the sceptre was stuck and nobody could remove it. Dutugamunu seeing this miracle constructed a Dagaba here. It is said the king called this stupa after a meal containing chillis (miris) which he forgot to present to the priest before consuming. The temple collapsed 1987 and it was restored leaving the parts of the former stupa in place. The new stupa is 59m high and 43m is diameter, something smaller than the original one.
An amazing site in Anuradhpura and this stupa is known to have been built by Kind Dutugemunu in the ancient days. A must visit.
